prior_works.title: Learn then Test: Calibrating Predictive Uncertainties by Controlling Risks
prior_works.authors: Anastasios N. Angelopoulos, Stephen Bates, Jitendra Malik, Michael I. Jordan
prior_works.role: Methodological foundation for distribution-free risk control via holdout calibration
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Deng et al. adopt and extend the LTT paradigm—searching over model/threshold choices and using a held-out set to certify a target risk—to certify constraints not just on expected loss or miscoverage, but on dispersion functionals of the entire loss distribution.

prior_works.title: Conformal Risk Control
prior_works.authors: Anastasios N. Angelopoulos, Stephen Bates, Emmanuel Candès, Michael I. Jordan, Tijana Zrnic
prior_works.role: General framework for finite-sample, distribution-free control of user-specified risk metrics
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The proposed dispersion-control framework builds directly on the CRC idea of distribution-free post-hoc auditing and threshold selection, generalizing the class of controllable objectives from event-based risks to dispersion measures that depend on the full loss CDF.

prior_works.title: Distribution-Free Predictive Inference for Regression
prior_works.authors: Jing Lei, Max G'Sell, Alessandro Rinaldo, Ryan J. Tibshirani, Larry Wasserman
prior_works.role: Foundational split conformal methodology enabling finite-sample guarantees under exchangeability
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper inherits the split-calibration blueprint of conformal prediction—fit on one split, certify on another—and repurposes it to certify bounds on loss-dispersion functionals rather than on coverage alone.

prior_works.title: Dvoretzky–Kiefer–Wolfowitz Inequality (with Massart’s sharp constant)
prior_works.authors: Aryeh Dvoretzky, Jack Kiefer, Jacob Wolfowitz; Pascal Massart
prior_works.role: Statistical tool for uniform, distribution-free control of empirical CDF deviations
prior_works.relationship_sentence: A key technical ingredient is uniform control of the empirical loss CDF; the authors leverage DKW to translate empirical dispersion estimates into finite-sample, distribution-free guarantees on the true dispersion.

prior_works.title: Fairness Without Demographics in Repeated Loss Minimization
prior_works.authors: Tatsunori B. Hashimoto, Megha Srivastava, Hongseok Namkoong, Percy Liang
prior_works.role: Motivational and conceptual link between tail/dispersion of losses and societal disparities
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By showing that controlling heavy-tail/worst-case losses can mitigate group disparities, this work motivates Deng et al.’s focus on directly constraining dispersion of individual losses with formal guarantees.

prior_works.title: Optimization of Conditional Value-at-Risk
prior_works.role: Definition and optimization of CVaR as a canonical tail/dispersion risk measure
prior_works.relationship_sentence: CVaR is a prototypical dispersion/tail functional that the new framework can control distribution-free; this paper provides the risk-measure formalism that underlies several objectives considered.

synthesis_narrative: Deng et al. extend the recent line of distribution-free risk control beyond expectations and coverage to dispersion measures of loss, which are central to societal concerns about unequal error burdens. The methodological backbone is the learn-then-test (LTT) and conformal risk control paradigm: train a flexible predictor, then use a held-out calibration set to certify that a user-specified risk stays below a target with finite-sample validity. Prior work operationalized this for event-based risks (e.g., miscoverage), but dispersion measures depend on the entire loss distribution, not just per-example indicators. To bridge this gap, the authors combine split-style calibration from conformal prediction with uniform empirical process control via the Dvoretzky–Kiefer–Wolfowitz inequality, allowing them to bound functionals that are Lipschitz or otherwise well-behaved with respect to the loss CDF. This mathematical move is what enables distribution-free guarantees for quantities like variance, interquantile range, or CVaR. Conceptually, fairness research—particularly the link between tail losses and group disparities—motivates targeting dispersion directly, while classic risk-measure theory (e.g., CVaR) supplies concrete objectives. Together, these strands yield a simple, plug-in framework: learn a model and tuning parameter, estimate the loss CDF on a calibration split, apply DKW-based confidence bands, and select settings that provably satisfy dispersion constraints at a chosen confidence level. The result is a general, distribution-free recipe that subsumes earlier risk-control methods and directly addresses inequality in model performance across individuals.
